etymologies: early 17th century; earliest use found in Richard Montagu (bap. 1575, d. 1641), bishop of Norwich and religious controversialist. From Byzantine Greek μυσταγωγικός mystagogic + -al

definitions: Of or relating to a mystagogue or mystagogy; concerned with instruction or initiation in religious mysteries.

notes.text: Frequently used with reference to St Cyril of Jerusalem's μυσταγωγικαὶ κατηχήσεις.
